awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Enabling Quantum Leap: Topological Nanoparticles as Potential Room-Temperature Qubits
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Over the past half century, computer chips have become smaller and faster, enabling a technological revolution that encompasses everything from cell phones to space ships. Unfortunately, further improvements in speed and miniaturization are limited by fundamental materials constraints. One solution is to move to quantum computation, a new type of computing that uses quantum science to conduct computations faster than traditional computers. Quantum computers, however, have very different material requirements than traditional computers. This project investigates a relatively new class of materials called topological insulators to see if they are suitable as a platform for quantum computation when confined to nanoscale dimensions. A partnership with the Delaware Teachers Institute lets the research team present a twelve-week seminar related to the research to local K-12 educators who create teaching modules based on the seminar content. The partnership also allows the principal investigators to recruit Research Experience for Teachers participants for hands-on summer research.
Technical description: Quantum computation relies on qubits, two-level systems that can be entangled and used to perform computations. Ideally, these qubits work at room temperature, are robust to decoherence, and may be fabricated by scalable methods. Theoretical predictions indicate that topological insulators confined to nanoscale dimensions can exhibit discrete surface states that retain the topological protection of the bulk material, reducing decoherence. The objective of this proposal is to explore the existence and properties of these states, to assess whether their inherent topological protection makes them viable as room-temperature qubits. Topological insulator films are grown using molecular beam epitaxy and patterned into nanoparticles using standard lithographic techniques before being characterized by optical spectroscopy. The aim is to understand how the discrete state energies vary with particle size and Fermi energy position. The goal of the project is to have detailed measurements of the optical properties of topological insulator nanoparticles, to assess their viability as an entirely new platform for topologically-protected room-temperature qubits. A partnership between the principal investigators and the Delaware Teachers Institute (DTI) allows the principal investigators to present a twelve-week seminar to local K-12 teachers on the optical properties of materials. The teachers then create units on this topic to disseminate through DTI channels, as well as for use in their own classrooms. Research Experience for Teachers supplements allow local teachers to take part in hands-on research on this project in the summers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to explore topological insulator nanoparticles (TI NPs) as potential qubits. Qubits are the fundamental components of a quantum computer. Unlike a classical bit, which is always either in the 0 state or the 1 state, a qubit can be in both simultaneously. Unfortunately, current qubits do not stay in the state they are put in for very long—they interact with the environment and decohere. We proposed to look at TI NPs as materials for qubits that would not decohere.

TIs are materials that have a topological band structure. Among other things, this means that TIs have surface states where the electrons physically reside at the surface of the material. The electrons in these surface states have a unique property in which their direction of travel determines their spin. This means that it is difficult for electrons to scatter into other states even when they interact with the environment. When we create NP from our TIs, the NPs have discrete energy levels, meaning that the electrons are only allowed to have specific energies. Theory predicts that the electrons occupying these discrete states should inherit the scattering resistance from the original surface states. This could lead to qubits that are resistant to decoherence, resulting in better quantum computers.

The first task for our project was to learn how to synthesize TI NPs. We took two approaches: fabricating NPs and directly growing NPs. In the first approach, we grew TI thin films using molecular beam epitaxy. In this way, we could create large-area high-quality thin films with defined thicknesses. After growth, we then developed a nanofabrication technique to etch the films into cylinders, creating TI NPs with well-defined diameters and positions. The advantage of this technique is that all of the NPs were uniform, which means we can measure many of them at once to get a larger signal. The disadvantage of this technique is that it requires us to etch the film, causing etch-induced damage to the TI NPs which may increase electron scattering. To solve this problem, we also developed a technique for synthesizing TI NPs directly. In this technique, we used molecular beam epitaxy to deposit droplets of bismuth on our substrates. Bismuth forms droplets due to its high surface tension. We then exposed the droplets to a selenium flux, turning them into NPs of Bi2Se3, a well-known TI. The benefit of this technique is that the self-assembly of the NPs means that they have no edge damage and thus less scattering. The downside is that the NPs are of a random size, meaning that if we tried to measure the entire chip at once, we would be unable to correlate the electron energy levels with the size of the NP.

After synthesis, we began to characterize the TI NPs. We tried five different techniques: angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES), time-domain terahertz spectroscopy (TDTS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), scanning tunneling spectroscopy (STS), and electrostatic force microscopy (EFM). ARPES measurements were designed to let us directly visualize the electron states. Unfortunately, these measurements were unsuccessful due to contamination of the sample surface. We tried a variety of techniques to solve this problem, but ultimately concluded that ARPES is not a viable technique to resolve the discrete states in TI NPs. Over the course of this project, we focused heavily on TDTS measurements, which also measure the entire chip at once. These measurements were done at the Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies (CINT) at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL). After multiple measurements and a significant amount of data analysis, we concluded that the signal from the substrate were swamping any signal we could get from the NPs. We have therefore paused these measurements until we can find a way to reduce the substrate signal. FTIR also measures the entire chip at once and has suffered from the same problem as TDTS, though attempts are ongoing to remove the substrate signal during the measurement process.

STS measures one particle at a time and looks for individual states. The initial results look promising for these materials, though more characterization is needed. Finally, the EFM technique is particularly well-suited for these samples. EFM has been used previously to look at discrete states in InAs quantum dots and in quantum dots in other systems. It is designed to work with “dirty” samples and does not require a high degree of surface cleanliness. Because it is a non-contact technique similar to atomic force microscopy, it can also work with samples that are not perfectly flat like the TI NPs. Initial data looks extremely promising and further characterization is ongoing. In addition to these efforts, we have worked with theory collaborators to develop more accurate models of these structures.
